children.text: Welcome to African Voices. I'm Larry Madowo in Ogun State, Western Nigeria. I've come
here to Abeokuta to interview Wole Shio Inka at his home. He just turned 90, but he's still
teaching and traveling. He was the first African to receive the Nobel Prize in Literature in
1986. We talked about his expansive body of work from novels to poetry to plays as well
as his political activism and what comes next. I was never satisfied with the way a story had
been told by the elders to us. I remember this because my siblings, my peers, would say no, no,
no. We didn't see that way. And I would say I know, but there's a way I want you to go. I am
Wole Shio Inka, playwright, essayist, novelist, poet, and activist. I hope through my work to
make changes in society. Professor Wole Shio Inka, thank you so much for talking to us. Pleasure. I
know you don't make a big fuss about your birthday, but you just turned 90, which is a big deal. So I
came all the way from Kenya to make a fuss. How does it feel? Well, that's the annoying thing,
that I don't feel 90. I think I just have taken birthdays for granted. Usually what I do on my
birthdays, I disappear into the forest. That's my normal way of spending birthdays. Wole Shio Inka
grew up in Abeokuta in the southwestern region of Nigeria when it was under British control. He
says he became politically aware by listening. I was a great eavesdropper on my parents on the
conversation going on, especially my father's colleagues. He was a headmaster teacher and he
had sort of a coterie of argumentative people. And I was sitting there, I remember behind an armchair,
listening. And so when the women rioted in this very town, Abeokuta, where we are now, my mother
was involved and she was a lieutenant of Mrs. Ranzom Kuti, Fela Kuti's mother. So as a child,
when all the rioting was taking place, I became a courier between the various women's camps,
passing messages. So I would say that this was the beginning of my political involvement. How old
were you at that time? That's a very good question. I don't think I was more than six. It was small
to pass through the legs of the police who were guarding that. Seeing your mother involved in this
political activism appeared to have planted the seed for your later work, essentially your life's
work. That's absolutely right. Being actually within the environment of that struggle of
militancy against an unacceptable situation. These women coming in, for instance, in the Kuti house,
to report their encounters at the hands of the, they were called a koda, the native police,
quote unquote, and how their goods were being seized in the marketplaces, they didn't pay taxes,
some of them beaten up, roughed up and so on. I took the side of the women, you know,
in a multilateral way. So that, yes, reflected in my writing, no question at all.
While Nigerians struggled for independence, he found his love for poetry and theater in primary
and secondary school. In his college years in Ibadan and later in Leeds, England, Wole immersed
himself in Nigerian politics and attuned his distant views. You were already from an early age
a good writer, you were writing poems and plays and why did you also decide that it was not just
enough to write, you also had to be politically active, you had to raise your voice to injustices
at great personal risk to you? Well, first of all, correction, I don't think I was a good writer at
that early age, no, but I wrote a lot. I had this vocation, let's put it this way, however childlike
it was quite early, again as a most natural aspect of my activities. Did I ever decide,
you know, deliberately to go into activism? I don't think so. They took what you might call
a decision regarding my future career, but then I found I could not really abandon one
for the other. But basically I knew that I was more inclined towards the creative aspect.
There's so many of us Africans who didn't live under colonization and so we don't know what that
was like. What was life then and compared to now? Oh, obviously at the time it was idyllic.
Idyllic even though it was full of stress and struggle, but that kind of struggle made sense.
You recognized it, the nature of it, the complexity of it, what things could be like if
society evolved along the kind of discussions which we listen to from the adults. Now it's
full of such complexities, such contradictions, such nuances which involve unfortunately life
and death decisions. We didn't have all those in my childhood. So there was a sense of
greater leisure, room for contemplation, you know, for even dreaming. These days things happen so
fast that I wonder if this young generation even has time to dream. Next, Wole tells me about the
cost of his civil disobedience and how he feels about the motion picture it inspired.
When I was a student, I thought our mission in life was to go down south and liberate
southern Africa. Before returning to Nigeria, we began to see that we'd better place our charity,
the priority of charity, on the home front. Wole Shoinka was a university in England in the
late 1950s during a time of apartheid in South Africa and a struggle for independence in Nigeria.
After graduating, one of his first major works, The Lion and the Jewel, was performed at the Royal
Court Theatre in London where he worked as a literary advisor. In 1960, he won the Rockefeller
Fellowship at Ibadong University and returned to a newly independent Nigeria. His criticism of
Nigerian politics continued with works like his satirical play about a fake prophet in
the trials of brother Jero. There's a legend here about you sneaking into a radio station
and swapping out a speech for something that was more critical and this has been told so many times
that it's a quite a life of its own. So what is the truth? Well, the first thing I have to remind
you is that I was tried and I quitted and if you ask that question it means you are questioning
the judicial system in this country. So let's take that for granted. Yes, it's true, there's
no point denying it any longer. It's true that I felt compelled to stop the further broadcast
of false results. I was part and parcel of the voting processes. I witnessed at first hand the
destruction of polling booths, even the tearing up of results. I was any badder at the time.
My colleagues, myself, we saw all this going on. When I saw this oppressive regime about to reinstate,
reinstall itself, and it was the most cynical, I have to, people have to remember that the most
cynical regime which went so far as to declare on radio at the time and television had begun
to say that we don't give a damn if you vote for us, the angels in heaven are already here. So it was
part of an ongoing struggle on so many levels. Yep, guilty, but it was, there was no alternative
approach at the time. Later, Wallace's actions would prove too much for the Nigerian government.
So you went to prison for 27 months, including 22 months in solitary confinement. What did that feel
like just because you were agitating for what you felt was right? It was a very testing period for
me. So it was not very easy, but in prison, I think one of the most cunning category of
humanity that I've ever encountered is the prisoner. Why? The prisoner has to survive.
So it's a survival test. It's not a question of self-advancement. So I began recollecting those
formulae in geometry, trigonometry, which I had hated. I began pulling them back and making
calculations on the ground. And I, believe it or not, I rediscovered the theory of permutations
and combinations. In prison? In prison. So the math you had hated in schools helped sustain you?
It became one of my exercises, the major one. Wallace tells me he wrote his famous prison notes
in isolation using meat bones, handmade ink and toilet paper. It recounts his political activism
and imprisonment for an alleged link to the Biafran army at the height of the Nigerian
civil war. A people have been subjected to a degree of inhuman violation. That memoir,
called The Man Died, was adapted into a film this year. How did you feel turning that dark period
into something people can watch? Let me put it this way, turning anything in my life into
something other people can watch pains me. I mean, it makes me, I don't mean physical hurt,
it makes me extremely uncomfortable. Why? I have no idea. For me it's just,
it's wrong to say it's horrific, let's just say that I'm detached from it. The one in which
we've collaborated was the one you're referring to, The Man Died, in which I assisted them in
trying to locate a building, a house, in which I hid and operated during the civil war.
It's not just about me alone, this is also about a particular period. So you don't like to watch
anything adapted from your life or from your work? Very bad. Even this interview we're doing.
You won't watch it? I might watch it eventually, but not immediately.
Why? I don't know, it always takes a while to bring myself to watch me.
Next, Wole tells me about his bittersweet reality after receiving the Nobel Prize in Literature.
During Exile, Wole Shioinka published The Open Sore of a Continent, a personal narrative of
the Nigeria crisis, in 1996, criticizing the previous year's execution of Nigerian author
Ken Saroewa by dictator Sani Abacha. Despite being targeted, he never faltered from denouncing
corruption and oppression over the years. You were the first African to receive the
Nobel Prize in Literature in 1986, and it took a long time before we even had another African
receive that honor. What did that feel like at the time?
Isolated. I was most relieved when the next African came, because so much was demanded
of you. It was like overnight your constituency expanded, simply because you're an African,
you come from the African continent. But at the same time, especially in societies like ours,
it exposed you a lot more. I always remind people that one of the most brutal dictators we've
had here, Sani Abacha, would have gone to his grave a happy man if he'd hanged a Nobel laureate,
if he'd been able to put on his CV that I hanged a Nobel laureate. As it is, he had to be content
with hanging an activist, a writer, and his eight companions, Ken Saroewa I'm referring to.
So it exposed me also to very great dangers, because I refused to back down
on my beliefs, on my activities, simply because I'd become a Nobel laureate.
You're still a thorn in the flesh with the political class,
whether it's in your books, in your writing, in your... You're speaking out constantly. Why?
Oof. Last time I was asked this question, the answer which I gave, because the answer always
varies, I would say that, well, it must be something which I ate or drank as a child
when nobody was looking. And that's the most recent explanation. If you ask me tomorrow,
I might have a different one. I think that secretly I'm a glutton for tranquility,
for peace of mind, really, a closet glutton. And to arrive at that space of tranquility,
I have to do certain things, to be able to be totally at peace in there, feeling fulfilled
in there, but simply because I'm aiming for that space when I'm at peace internally.
That's another explanation, yes. This year, for his 90th birthday, Nigerian President
Bolatinubu renamed Nigeria's National Theatre after him, honoring Wole's legacy.
While his town of Abeokuta celebrated his contributions,
supporting young critical thinkers through the Wole Shioinka International Cultural Exchange
Project. Are you reading any of your students? You said Henry Louis Gates was your student,
for instance. Oh, yes, I think. I'm not going to mention names so as not to create any videos,
but I read my students and I even have helped promote a number of my student work. You write
novels, you write plays, you write poetry, and guerrilla theatre, your plays, you call them.
Do you have a favorite genre? Well, I think theatre is my most,
it suits my temperament best, yes, because it's constantly a work in progress. Even after you've
written it, it goes into production, variation, adaptation, I think theatre.
Next, Wole takes me to his place of tranquility.
So even the corridor has artwork everywhere. Yes, most of these are modern, whereby young
covers in the tradition. Your house here in Abeokuta is like a museum come art gallery.
What is the story behind all these pieces around us? I think an expression of substitution.
Sometimes I enjoy my solitude enormously. I think you mentioned that about a thousand times
so far. I do, I do. So I think maybe secretly I long for company and that's why
I accumulate all this. The company of inanimate objects, they can't talk back to you.
They can't talk back. But they're there, they are presences, they create
a micro community of their own, a very special kind. First of all, the expatriate community.
Much of that community robbed us blind. Each time they were going home, their suitcases were full of
this. And when I came back and was a fellow at the University of Ibarra, I ran into much of this
larceny, bold, brave, in your face larceny. I mean, you'd be surprised how deep this runs
in our society, even till today. Nigeria is a really religious country. People are deeply
Christian or Muslim. And you have resisted the forces of faith in that traditional sense for
a long time. How come? Yeah, I was fortunate to be born into two worlds, if you like,
a Christian world and then in Ishaara, the traditional orisha worshipper. I was my
grandfather until the poor man also got converted. He was an orisha person, he was a chief.
And his side fascinated me a lot more. It was more artistic for me, more creative,
and also more mysterious. I don't find much of the mysterious in Christianity. I mean,
even less in Islam, for the simple reason that I didn't grow up in a Muslim environment. Orisha
is open, very ecumenical. That's why these foreign so-called world religions were able to penetrate,
and even distort the truth. The orisha is so, because of this generosity of spirit,
it's not violent. It's one of those African religions which eschew violence. It's telling
the level to which most of Africa has been evangelized, either for Christianity or Islam,
that most people consider you an atheist. Well, I'm an atheist in their sense, absolutely. I'm
an atheist. I don't believe in the Islamic God, I don't believe in the Christian God.
And for these religions, it means you're an atheist. So I say, yes, I'm an atheist. But I
insist that all human beings, they have a certain spiritual core in their being. I believe myself to
be more a spirit-sensitive person. You have a reforestation project here in Abeokuta, the
autonomous republic of Ijigba. When I moved in here, it was entirely forested. All these
were my hunting ground. I really felt I was in a different country, and I could just stay here
and cut off the rest of society. Wole embraces this time of his life with a little bit of dark
humor. What you see when you come in there, on this side. Where it says the trespassing cows will be
hanged. All that area, complete reforestation. So it's literally back to its natural something.
Anyway, having recreated nature, don't I deserve to give it a name of my own?
I think it's only right. It's only fair.
Now that you have your own little piece of earth here, what's in your future?
Future?
Future, I don't want to be morbid, but you know that's the future.
But I made arrangements for that within this state.
That is the most morbid answer anyone has ever given me.
That I made arrangements for my death.
Many people don't like to hear it. As I say it all the time, I won't say it here. You are CNN,
everybody knows what I'm talking about. It's where we're all headed, is the future for everybody.
In terms of productivity, the immediate thing is to go on a vacation. Take a resolution
which will be attested judicially, not to grant any more interviews.
On pain of penalty, which will be recorded. No more interviews.
I'm glad we got this in.
Certainly not writing. Possibly trying to resume certain activities will give me pleasure,
which I consciously and rigorously cut off to be able to pursue my vocation.
Because I'm not going to sit on that. I'll also get into a vehicle somewhere, I don't care,
or in the world and sit for about a week or two weeks and just be tourists. I'm looking forward to that.
And that's our show. Thank you so much for watching. All our shows are on our website,
so you can binge watch all of them. The website cnn.com slash African Voices. And keep up with us
on our social media. I'm Larry Medowo in Abeokuta, Nigeria, and I'll see you next time.
